text.value: Three letters for district then 2-3 numbers
If burn occurred over many years, record the year for the site you are analysing
Are you located at the boundary between two severity classes that are each at least 10m across?
Select the severity class on either side of you (choose 2-3).
Does the severity you see around you match the severity class shown on the map?
No it does not match or Not sure

Approximate the percentage of area not burned. Choose either a percentage or a descriptive option (e.g., patch number/size). A large patch is at least 2 m by 2 m. A small patch is smaller than 2 m by 2 m.
Broken leaf pieces that form a type of decomposing mulch under the litter layer. If necessary, scrape down to mineral soil to see how deeply the char has penetrated.
Take a landscape photo of ground surface.
Estimate how much area the elevated fuel covered before the burn. First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much of the original crown is intact and still green?
Take a photo of tall shrubs/bare sticks or juvenile trees.
Most common trees seen in midstorey layer.
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
How much area did the midstorey fuel cover before the burn? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much original crown is intact and still green?
How high does fresh black char extend up the midstorey trees?
Take a photo of the midstorey crowns or midstorey stems.
Dominant vegetation of canopy before burn
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
How much area did the over-storey/canopy fuel cover before the burn? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much of the original crown is intact and still green?
How much ground is covered by canopy or midstorey leaves dropped post-fire?
How high does fresh black char extend up the trees in this stratum?
Take a photo looking up into the canopy.
Do you want to collect severity metrics to confirm the class?

Estimate the percentage of area not burned. Choose either a percentage or a descriptive option (e.g., patch number/size). A large patch is at least 2 m by 2 m. A small patch is smaller than 2 m by 2 m.
Broken leaf pieces that form a type of decomposing mulch under the litter layer. If necessary, scrape down to mineral soil to see how deeply the char has penetrated.
Take a landscape photo of ground surface.
Estimate how much area the elevated fuel covered before the burn. First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much of the original crown is intact and still green?
Take a photo of tall shrubs/bare sticks or juvenile trees.
Most common trees seen in midstorey layer.
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
How much area did the intermediate/understorey fuel cover before the burn? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much original crown is intact and still green?
How high does fresh black char extend up the midstorey trees?
Take a photo of the midstorey crowns or midstorey stems.
Dominant vegetation of canopy before burn
Record first few letters of species common name or Scientific name (genus/species). i.e., for Jarrah use 'Jar' or 'Eucmar'
How much area did the over-storey/canopy fuel cover before the burn? First ask, was it more than half (50%)? Then ask if it was more than 25% or more than 75%.
How much of the original crown is intact and still green?
How much ground is covered by canopy or midstorey leaves dropped post-fire?
How high does fresh black char extend up the canopy trees?
Take a photo looking up into the canopy.
Does the boundary shown on the map match what you see around you?
Any observations or comments you'd like to add.
